Prompt: My husband works a lot which really helps our family. The problem is he never wants to go anywhere with my children and me. When he gets home from work, he’s highly irritable and often goes around the house criticizing me for practically everything. Cleaning, watching the kids, what I did or didn’t do during the day, Ext. Most every time I talk with him, he has something negative to say about me. Something I didn’t do right. This is really starting to wear on me. My Self Esteem is pretty bad and this makes it worse. I also get very anxious when I know he’s coming home soon, because I know it is going to be constant critiques. Also, when I ask him if he wants to go someplace with me and the kids, he never wants to and gets upset about it. I get in a bad mood too and he ends up leaving. In which doesn’t make any sense because he said he didn’t want to go anywhere. I have told him how much these things bother me. Every time, he turns around and says what bother him. Nothing gets resolved. I work from home and it’s difficult because I am also watching the kids. He doesn’t like anyone else watching the kids so I try to the majority of the time, unless I have somewhere important to go to. We used to be a lot different. We would go out to dinner, shopping, ext. We would watch TV together and he really didn’t critique me all too much. He used to say good things about me in which he doesn’t say anymore. For example, he used to call me “pretty girl”. He has not said that for awhile now. We have also went through some crap that hurt our relationship. I wasn’t very mature when we started dating so I made some poor decisions that I would never do presently. I’d love to know what changed our relationship so much? Is he acting like this for revenge or because he’s not happy? I can honestly say I’m miserable when I’m around him. I cannot say I’m overall miserable because I do enjoy spending time with my children. My underneath layer is hurt, badly. I feel like my feelings don’t matter. I don’t know when and if to call it quits. We have been married for 6 years and I don’t give up easily. I do love him but I wish he was how he was when we got married. He actually cared and SHOWED me how much he loved me.
Response:
Explanation:
The person in the anecdote is experiencing a pattern of negative interactions with their husband, where they feel constantly criticized, belittled, and unheard. They mention feeling anxious and miserable around him, and that their self-esteem has been negatively affected by his behavior. The person also expresses feelings of hurt, frustration, and uncertainty about whether to continue the relationship.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortions present in this anecdote are:

* Personalization: The person is holding themselves personally responsible for their husband's negative behavior, as if they are somehow causing it.
* Labeling: The person has labeled themselves as "miserable" and feeling like their feelings don't matter, which can perpetuate a negative self-image.
* Fortune-telling: The person is predicting that things will always result in the worst possible outcome when interacting with their husband (e.g. "I know it's going to be constant critiques").
* Overgeneralization: The person is drawing sweeping conclusions about their relationship and their husband's behavior, such as saying they're "miserable" around him all the time.
* Emotional Reasoning: The person is believing that their feelings of anxiety and hurt are true, without considering alternative perspectives or facts.

It's worth noting that these distortions may be contributing to the person's negative emotions and uncertainty about their relationship.

These distortions may be contributing to the person's negative thought patterns and behaviors.

Prompt: My husband’s uncle has great financial means however spends extremely little money on entertainment. He showed up unannounced for years often at supper hour and whenever he liked. After his girlfriend broke up with him his intrusions worsened. We repeatedly asked him to call before he came, but he would show up anyway and say “If you are busy I just go.” If we say we are busy he argues. Visits are often and prolonged. Finally, after waking us up one morning I firmly told him that he was asked to call and repeatedly violates our request. His first response was “You don’t like me.” I am also sick with Lupus and when this first big argument came I was caring for several children. He didn’t come unannounced nor even when invited for about 6 months and then out of the blue he started again. Then came the argument followed by absence then another 6 months all would start again. This cycle has been going on for about 5 years now. My husband and I explained why we needed him to call and he nodded his head as though he understood. After these talks I made sure to invite him over so that he would know he would be able to visit. His response is usually the same. “I may come, not sure what I am doing yet.” That ends up tying up our night as we don’t know if he is coming or not. If we invite others to play cards we may not be able to if he just shows up. Hubby feels guilty telling him that we are not up for company. It is badly straining our marriage as I can’t even rely on having a peaceful night. Hubby is stressed because he doesn’t want him doing it either but would put up with it if I didn’t complain. He also is extremely rude to us and other guests. He says and does mean things when he perceives an injustice towards him. Everything mean thing he does (which is often) seems to be calculated to send a message. The last 7 out of 8 invites we gave he caused issues. A pharmacist friend of mine told me to read “Controlling People” and I was shocked at how much scenarios in the book resembled this relative. How can I help my husband not feel guilty about insisting his uncle respect boundaries? My husband tries, then his uncles manipulates him and my husband yells at me as to why he can’t come over when he wants. (From Canada)
Response:
Explanation:
Upon reading the anecdote, it appears that the speaker's husband is being manipulated by his uncle, who consistently disregards boundaries and expects special treatment. The uncle's behavior is causing stress and strain on the marriage, with the husband feeling guilty about asserting their needs.

The husband's guilt and willingness to accommodate his uncle's demands seem to be driven by a desire not to hurt or offend him. However, this approach only leads to further manipulation and conflict.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortion present in this situation appears to be:

*   **Personalization**: The speaker feels that her husband is being manipulated by his uncle, but she also takes on the responsibility of managing her husband's guilt and stress related to their uncle's behavior. This suggests that she may be holding herself personally responsible for events beyond her control.
*   **Should Statements**: The husband's expectation that he should accommodate his uncle's demands, even if it causes stress and strain on their marriage, is a classic example of a "should" statement.

These distortions can lead to feelings of powerlessness, anxiety, and conflict in relationships.

Prompt: I am a co-facilitator (pro bono, unlicensed) for a men’s DV group (court-mandated) at a non-profit. The leader is a therapist who also has a private practice. In group one of the men mentioned fear of losing his probation for something he didn’t do and being imprisoned for years at an upcoming hearing. He didn’t return to the group after the hearing. She discovered he indeed had been jailed with another hearing soon to determine whether he will be imprisoned. He’s made enormous progress, despite a terrible childhood and adverse family dynamics, he has a good heart and reaches out to other group members, attends a drug-tested substance abusers group three times a week, and has focused on becoming a father again to his children (they were not the recipients of his abuse). But he’s also expressed suicidal thoughts in the past in the context of never wanting to go back to prison, and he’s become worn out and depressed in dealing with The System (frequent court hearings, probation officers, in-laws, etc. – you can imagine), and we’re deeply concerned about his mental health. He’s received no visitors. LA County is under a DOJ consent agreement to improve its mental health resources, but there have been numerous suicides nonetheless. The therapist is considering visiting the client in jail to check on his health and give him moral support, to let him know someone cares. But she and the non-profit center are conflicted about ethics and boundaries and dual relationships – she says this issue was never discussed in school or workshops, and the non-profit doesn’t even have a policy because this issue has never arisen before. I think it’s because the people setting boundaries aren’t the kind of people who go to jail very often. A large proportion of the country’s 2 million prisoners have some degree of mental illness and get almost no care. He hasn’t called — he’s expressed a sense of unworthiness that might keep him from calling. I don’t think this is the usual ethics and boundaries issue, and I think in these circumstances the benefit for man’s mental health and maybe even his life far outweighs the boundary risk. What do you think? It seems a Catch-22, but shouldn’t be, given the problem of mental illness in prisons.
Response:
Explanation:
The anecdote describes a complex situation where the therapist is torn between her professional ethics and boundaries, and her concern for the client's well-being. The client has made significant progress despite his difficult circumstances, but is now facing a potentially life-threatening situation due to his incarceration. The therapist feels that visiting him in jail would be beneficial for his mental health, but is hesitant due to concerns about ethics and boundaries.

Distortion Present: Y

My thought process suggests that the following distortions might be present:

* Overgeneralization: The non-profit center's lack of policy on visiting clients in jail is attributed to the fact that "the people setting boundaries aren't the kind of people who go to jail very often". This statement generalizes a specific group of people and implies that they are not empathetic or understanding.
* Personalization: The therapist feels personally responsible for the client's well-being, which might lead her to prioritize his needs over professional ethics. She also mentions that she hasn't discussed this issue in school or workshops, implying that it's a personal failing on her part.
* Fortune-telling: The therapist predicts that visiting the client in jail would be beneficial for his mental health and might even save his life. While this is a possible outcome, it's an uncertain prediction that assumes a specific result without considering other possibilities.

These distortions might contribute to the therapist's conflicted feelings about visiting the client in jail, and could influence her decision-making process.

I have spoken to my mother and a few of my friends about how I am feeling which helps me feel less stressed but five minutes later to an hour I convince myself that all I have said was a lie and I am deep in denial, which makes me more depressed.  I don’t know what I am feeling and it scares the hell out of me. The person is also experiencing extreme distress when they think about being gay or in a relationship with a woman, which suggests a strong emotional investment in maintaining a certain identity.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortions present in this anecdote are:

*   Emotional Reasoning: The individual believes "I feel that way, so it must be true" (i.e., they assume their intense anxiety and fear of being gay means they actually are gay).
*   Fortune-telling: They predict a catastrophic outcome if they are indeed gay (e.g., losing interest in men, feeling like a "closeted gay").
*   Mind Reading: They attribute negative reactions to others (e.g., assuming friends and family will think they're gay or that they'll be judged).
*   Magnification: They exaggerate the significance of their feelings and thoughts, making them feel overwhelming and insurmountable.
*   Personalization: They take on excessive responsibility for events beyond their control (e.g., feeling like they've lost their identity).

These distortions contribute to the individual's distress and make it challenging for them to think rationally about their situation.

Prompt: Need help dealing with high conflict ex-wife of boyfriend. They share custody of 3 teens; divorced 7 years. Distortion Present: Y

The distortion present here seems to be related to:

* Emotional Reasoning: Believing "I feel that way, so it must be true" (e.g., the boyfriend feels guilty for not letting his ex-wife stay longer with the dogs).

However, the most prominent distortion present in this anecdote seems to be:

* Personalization: Holding oneself personally responsible for events beyond one’s control. The boyfriend feels guilty and responsible for his ex-wife's behavior and the stress it causes him, even though he's taking steps to change the dynamic.

It's essential to recognize that the boyfriend is not solely responsible for his ex-wife's actions or the consequences of her behavior. He's doing his best to set boundaries and prioritize his own well-being and that of his children.

Distortion Present: Y

* Fortune-telling: They predict that treating personality disorders may not be curable and that treatment may only relieve some symptoms, leading them to feel hopeless about their prospects for change.

She won’t sleep, eat, or take the meds that the hospital is giving her so they are now going to transfer her to a mental facility. Please help my understand what is happening. This is not my mother and I am so confused. Is my mother going to stay this way? Please respond.

Explanation: It seems like your mother's behavior is becoming increasingly erratic, paranoid, and detached from reality. The fact that she's accusing her husband of stealing her car, erasing family numbers from her phone, and hiding under the bed, suggests a disconnection from what's actually happening around her.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortion present in this situation appears to be a combination of several cognitive distortions:

*   **Fortune-telling**: Your mother is predicting that her husband is trying to harm her or erase her identity.
*   **Mind Reading**: She believes her husband is thinking negatively about her and plotting against her, without any basis in fact.
*   **Overgeneralization**: She's drawing sweeping conclusions from limited instances (e.g., hiding under the bed) and assuming that these events are part of a larger conspiracy.

These distortions might be indicative of a more serious underlying issue, such as dementia or a psychotic episode. It's essential to consult with medical professionals for an accurate diagnosis and guidance on how to support your mother during this challenging time.

In terms of her condition, it's difficult to predict whether she'll stay in this state indefinitely. However, the fact that she's not recognizing her own family members, is detached from reality, and is refusing treatment suggests a severe cognitive impairment. A mental facility may be able to provide her with the necessary care and support to address these issues.

It's understandable that you're feeling confused and concerned about your mother's situation. Reaching out to medical professionals, support groups, or online resources can help you better understand what's happening and find ways to cope with this challenging time.

Explanation:
Upon reading the anecdote, it appears that the individual is experiencing a multitude of negative thoughts, emotions, and behaviors. They seem to be overwhelmed by stress, have difficulty concentrating, and are plagued by self-doubt and feelings of inadequacy. The person also exhibits avoidance behaviors (e.g., calling in sick, struggling with exams), engages in self-destructive habits (e.g., excessive talking to themselves, pulling their lip skin, scratching their head), and has suicidal thoughts.

The individual's thought patterns seem to be characterized by an excessive focus on negative aspects, a tendency to catastrophize situations, and a general sense of hopelessness. They also appear to be overly self-critical, with a strong emphasis on their perceived flaws and shortcomings.

Distortion Present: Y

Based on the information provided, I would identify several cognitive distortions present in this anecdote:

1. **Overgeneralization**: The individual tends to draw sweeping negative conclusions about themselves and their abilities.
2. **Mental Filter**: They focus primarily on limited negative aspects of themselves and their experiences, while neglecting excessive positive ones.
3. **Magnification**: The person exaggerates or catastrophizes the outcome of certain events or behaviors (e.g., feeling overwhelmed by stress, struggling with exams).
4. **Personalization**: They hold themselves personally responsible for events beyond their control (e.g., worrying about their dad's financial situation).
5. **Labeling**: The individual attaches negative labels to themselves (e.g., "I'm a failure," "I'm not good enough").
6. **Fortune-telling**: They predict that an event will always result in the worst possible outcome (e.g., feeling like they'll never pass a course, worrying about their dad's financial situation).
7. **Emotional Reasoning**: The person believes their emotions are facts (e.g., "I feel awful about myself, so it must be true").
8. **Should Statements**: They expect things or personal behavior to be a certain way (e.g., feeling like they should be able to pass exams, expecting themselves to be more confident).
9. **All-or-Nothing Thinking**: The individual exhibits binary thought patterns, considering anything short of perfection as a failure.
10. **Mind Reading**: They conclude that others are reacting negatively to them without any basis in fact (e.g., feeling like people don't like them).

Please note that these distortions might not be exhaustive, and the individual may exhibit other cognitive biases not mentioned here.

I am a visual thinker, which I guess is why these thoughts seems so lifelike. These thoughts also come very sudden, and are related to the present situation I am in. I am right now in a relationship with my girlfriend and we have a child (2 years old) and two cats. I have had previous thoughts of harming my girlfriend, which is usual to me since I get these thoughts often towards other humans. On the other hand it started bothering me when I got very strong, visual impulses to hurt our infant child. I got real reason to worry since I have never been good to remember any dreams, but the last two or three I can remember involves harming or killing our daughter, which is very distressfull. Sometimes these impulses can be very hard to handle, which is the reason why I chose to register on this website. We got a new kitten the other day, and even that she is in a new location, she has adapted very well. But due to something as simple as her not wanting a cuddle drove both thoughts and action to treat her very aggressively and rough. Stopping myself from harming it, I had to sit alone in 15 minutes to calm myself down. I am concerned that if I can’t control my impulses to something as innocent as a kitten, what can happen in the future towards my daughter? Thanks for helping.
Response:
Explanation:
The individual describes experiencing recurring and intense visual thoughts of harming others, including their girlfriend and infant child. They express concern about losing control over these impulses and potentially harming their daughter. The thoughts seem to be triggered by specific situations or emotions.

Distortion Present: Y (Multiple distortions present)

Possible distortions:

1. Overgeneralization - The individual generalizes that they will inevitably harm their daughter because of past experiences with similar impulses.
2. Fortune-telling - They predict a negative outcome (harming their daughter) based on past thoughts and impulses, without considering the possibility of change or intervention.
3. Magnification - The individual exaggerates the severity of their impulses and potential consequences, making it seem like an inevitable disaster.
4. Personalization - They take sole responsibility for controlling their impulses, implying that they are solely to blame if something goes wrong.

It's essential to note that these distortions might be contributing factors to the individual's distress, but a comprehensive evaluation by a mental health professional would be necessary to determine the underlying causes and develop an effective plan.

Prompt: I didn’t realize I was suffering from depression until many years into it. I finally went to a psychologist and psychiatrist when my life was falling apart. I felt awful and had felt awful for a very long time, but after getting on medications and feeling like a normal, happy person for a couple years, it all felt like an old unreal dream. So I decided to stop my medications. My doctors advised me against it, saying that if I had suffered more than 3 episodes, I should stay on medication indefinitely, but I had never “counted” my episodes. Really, it just felt like I was born with one long and nasty episode. I have been off my meds for a month now and I feel horrible. My anxiety is so bad that my whole body hurts from being so tense and shaky. I’m missing work either because I’m too busy crying or I just don’t want to deal with life. I feel lonely, sad, and hopeless. I feel like I am cursed for life. From what I have read and heard, depression occurs in episodes. But I feel like I am doomed to feel like this forever, having no respite unless I take high doses of medications. Is it possible that I just have a “lifetime long episode”? I only went to see a psychiatrist when I was 22, about a year after I moved out of my parents house. My parents are deniers of mental illness – the have a “pick yourself up by your bootstraps” / “you can’t possibly have depression” attitudes, so I always attributed my poor mental status to a character flaw. But when I reflect on my childhood and adolescence, I don’t ever remember being happy. I think I was always depressed. I cannot possibly live my life feeling this depressed but I don’t want to take medication for the rest of my life either. I haven’t even mentioned that my medications and behavioral therapies have done absolutely nothing to help my OCD. That I have heard can last a lifetime. I don’t think I can live like this. It’s getting to be too much. It can all be tolerated until you realize that, for the rest of your existence, none of this will go away.
Response:
Explanation:
The person in the anecdote is experiencing a significant emotional distress and is struggling with the idea of living with depression and OCD for their entire life. They are also grappling with the concept of "episodes" and whether they can be considered as having one long episode rather than multiple episodes. This suggests that they might be trying to make sense of their situation in a way that feels more manageable.

Distortion Present: Y

The distortion present here appears to be Overgeneralization, specifically drawing sweeping negative conclusions with limited instances. The person is generalizing their current state as being the only possible reality for their entire life, without considering other possibilities or perspectives. They are also overestimating the duration and severity of their symptoms, which can lead to feelings of hopelessness and despair.

Additionally, there might be a hint of Fortune-telling, predicting that an event (in this case, not taking medication) will always result in the worst possible outcome. However, Overgeneralization seems to be the primary distortion at play here.
